displayed_text: Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down. Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get --

Family Member: February fifth till – Doctor: Oh yeah, because even if you start in January, it’s monthly, so. Family Member: So February fifth till like the twenty, till like the twenty-second or something. Doctor: Oh that’s fine. That’s fine. Family Member: So we have to schedule that around then. Doctor: Oh yeah, he’ll, trust me, we will hunt you down. He will hunt you down because every time you’re about to get a dose, it’s fifteen thousand dollars a dose. Family Member: Oh my god! Doctor: When I say we got to get insurance right, we got to get insurance right. But we also, they don’t mix it; they don’t pop the tab unless you’re around because there’s no re-do. Once you (makes sound) Family Member: So, so. Is this going to make him sleepless, like you said a little more energy? Doctor: No, no, it’s only going to help with pain and I think when you get off the Xtandi you’ll actually have more energy because no matter what that Xtandi is making you tired. Patient: Well my energy level isn’t bad. Doctor: Yeah, to you, but we’ve got this one over here going “Heh?” (Chuckles)

Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller? Patient: Much smaller, yeah. Doctor: Draining, or? Patient: Oh, yeah. It’ll drain a little bit, you know, every day. It’s kinda gotten, you can feel it’s a little hard right here, like a hard lump. Doctor: And you’re not on any antibiotics? Patient: No, no. So, they think it’s a combination of the Xgeva and the, uh, oral surgery I had a year ago. Doctor: Anything else going on?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: That vaccine therapies tend to work a little better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So with that, that’s why I think it would be a great next stop to do. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We would have to get clearance from insurance because it’s about a hundred thousand bucks. Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up.

Patient: Nope. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay. And we talked last time about whether you want a call from the quit line to help you quit. The answer’s no because you just told me you don’t want to quit. Patient: No. That’s the least of my trouble. I ain’t going to do it. Doctor: I tell you ever you and I have the same birthday? Patient: Yeah. (Laughs) Doctor: So comes in for follow-up. How have you been? Patient: Well, besides that, huh, that pain I’m still getting. Except for now I’m getting a pain right here. I’m thinking this is from this. I’m not sure. But, huh- Doctor: So where’s the pain at that you had before? Patient: Down in here. Doctor: In your buttock? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or it’s hips and buttock?

Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: It looks, I know it’s got a little scab to it. Patient: Well, that’s because I take my fingernail and I scratch it. And the only reason I scratch it is because when your shirt hits it, it hurts. You told me to mention everything. Are these cameras on? Doctor: They are. Patient: With me, me running off at the jaws. Doctor: Today, your white count is fine. Your anemia is unchanged. So that’s normal when you’re on these medicines a lower testosterone. Your platelets are also normal. Kidney function looks good. Your albumin is better. Your alkaline phosphatase is the same. Everything else is normal.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, I’m planning on getting scans next week and seeing Patient: Okay. Doctor: You anyway. So, within a week or two, I’ll be able to tell you. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: What we are doing. Okay. The Zytiga, now this is a very specialized medication because it’s for cancer. Okay. So, we will need to send it to a mail order pharmacy. There are these specialty pharmacies Patient: Mmm, Okay. Doctor: That deal with this medication. So, Patient: Because I’ve got a mail order through my job, too. Doctor: Which one? Patient: My mail order is called E-h-i-m. They deal with mail order prescriptions. Doctor: Okay. This one, though, has to go to a specialty pharmacy.

Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you. Doctor: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse. Family Member: Right. That’s good. Doctor: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else. Family Member: That’s a blessing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I’m good with that. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Alright?

Patient: And occasionally I’ll swing I’ll get a zinger down here and that’s from back there you know. And the neurologist told me to quit playing. Doctor: Yeah I was gonna ask you did you check with the neurosurgeon if it’s safe to do it. Patient: Oh yeah. Nah, it’s not safe. Doctor: It doesn’t sound safe. Patient: No. Doctor: Oh you’re just preferring to not get … Patient: Well I got a… Doctor: But you don’t want to. Patient: I got to address that. I got to address that and… Doctor: All the more reason to do surgery if it holds up your paddleball and all that stuff right? Patient: Well maybe, yeah, right. Family Member: Well what the – will that lesions – his legs are really weak and they hurt. Would that lesion? Patient: It’s not bad is it?

Family Member: And tired. Doctor: Yeah. Especially now, I’m not even doing a thing to poison you, you should feel better. Doctor: Um hum. So is that the highest? Patient: So absolutely. Absolutely. I don’t, I don’t get readings like that. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know? It can be in the two twenties. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Which is too high. Doctor: Yeah. Less than two hundred would be great. Patient: But, but, uh, you know, but with the pump I give daily bolus myself. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Yes. Patient: So, uh, even, even in all the frequent trips have to wake up in the morning and have to urinate, I check my sugar. Doctor: Okay. And? Are you okay at night?

Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it?

Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright, and uh, I do need to feel your tummy. (Dr. examining patient) Patient: Mm hmm. Doctor: And urine, no problems? Patient: No problems. Doctor: Ok. So should we go back on the chemo?

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: Well, I think I’m dandy. The question is are you dandy? Family Member: Right. We haven’t got the blood work back yet, so. Doctor: Yeah. PSA’s not back. The rest of you is actually okay. Family Member: He was going through, he went through a rough time after radiation. You probably talked to the other doctor. I mean he was on his hands and knees with his head on the couch. And I went, J___, you need to go up and get in bed. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He was pretty bad. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking.

Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: When, when we went to Langa, that was, that was different than where they was going. So we, we, they had a package to go to Langa. We went to- Doctor: What’s Langa? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right. Family Member: Very poor. It’s like they forgot about that part. Patient: You ain’t lying. Family Member: Because we added Robben Island, and so they added that part so we could go see that. That’s the first history over there. Patient: Yeah. So we had a tour guide when we went there. Doctor: And where’s that? That’s where Mandela was, right? Patient: Right.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The reason is so you know everybody wants to be helpful and you know give you all kinds of natural products and things like mistletoe or kabuki mushrooms or whatever. The problem is that a lot of them are antioxidants. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So they’re really good stuff, except when you’re trying to kill bad things, and then they interfere because one of the things we’re trying to do in chemo is make reactive oxygen species which kill, make the DNA not work and breaks up and then the cells break up. If you give a medicine like mistletoe to interfere with the creation of those uh you know, what’s basically hydrogen peroxide that kills ah the cells, then you’re interfering with chemotherapy and radiation therapies. Family Member: The effectiveness of the chemo Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called Doctor: Hmmmm Patient: Should I hold off on that during the period of treatment as well? Doctor: So, so, yes. Uhm um they have some things that interfere with what we do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so I’m you know all holistic approaches for all these things. I can tell you back in the day I wrote books about this stuff. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Other: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Other

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
